item.title: Mr Douglas calls time on a successful Junior Branch career
item.description:
News
BY JONATHAN TANG

After 13 years at the helm of the UCS Junior Branch, Mr. Douglas is to retire at the end of the next academic year. The 57-year-old, who succeeded Mr. John Hubbard in 1999, has enjoyed a lengthy and distinguished Headship.

Previously the Deputy Head of Belmont school, Mr. Douglas will certainly have left an impression on the J.B. with significant changes to the site layout, entrance exams process and use of computer technology at Holly Hill.

In the last decade or so, he has notably removed dormitories for teachers to sleep in, which have now become the site of Year Three classrooms, as well as the removal of 8+ applications  - in favour of a more widespread 7+ pupil enrolment system  - and the introduction of the ICT in the entire junior school.

"Time and effort"
Mr. Douglas also committed time and effort into engendering a distinctive character to the UCS Junior Branch, partly by placing more emphasis on music, drama and art. In 2010, the school won the prestigious Gold Artsmark Award.


"Caring, enthusiastic, positive"

Pragmatically, he has decided to remain as Headmaster for another year in order to facilitate the appointment of his successor. He is also thought to have assisted the transition between Mr. Durham and Mr. Beard at the Senior School.

In an interview with an education website, Mr. Douglas said that his ideal pupil is "happy and confident with a wide range of interests." He also professed that parents living in northwest London have the hardest choice of schools owing to the broad variety of options.

"Key to success"
He based his ethos on Charles Symonds, first Headmaster of the Junior Branch, and said in his first address to his parents: "If a child is happy and active, he'll learn." Douglas firmly believes that this is still the key to success in a student's education. 

The UCS Council said in a statement regarding the appointment of Mr. Douglas' successor: "The successful candidate will be part of an exciting future for the UCS family of schools, delivering a vision which builds on existing strengths to lead the Junior Branch through the next phase of its development."

item.title: Community Action favourites old and new converge in 2013 campaign
item.description:
News
BY ALEX CEDAR

The annual Community Action campaign is back for the second half of the Autumn term and naturally promises to be bigger and more explosive than ever.

This year's charities come from completely different ends of the spectrum, with the School set to raise money for worthy causes across the globe. These include a Save the Children fund for young people in Syria and water charity WaterAid, as well as local charities such as the London-based Mousetrap Theatre Projects.

Students of all year groups are planning an array of fundraisers to aid these organisations. The programme not only welcomes back old favourites from recent years, including Jonathan Tang’s inimitable 5-a-side football tournament, but incorporates a multitude of new events.

"Long-awaited return"
The long-awaited return of UCS does Strictly Come Dancing - featuring a cornucopia of UCS teachers - returns after a five year absence. This glamorous bonanza will take place in the Great Hall after school on Monday, 2nd December and will be presided over by a mystery judging panel.

The following day will mark the return of one of last year's Community Action triumphs, as the critically-acclaimed Take Me Out UCS takes place for a second time. Having been mentioned in Tatler magazine, the 2013 edition will be held in the Great Hall and the organising committee has set up a website to display event details at www.tmoucs.co.uk.

Meanwhile, the recognised stalwarts of Community Action are due to re-emerge - in the form of the all-conquering, coin-guzzling enterprise that is the Cookie Store, in addition to the ever-popular Battle of the Bands, where the Great Hall will yet again be filled with a cacophony of melodic chaos, much to the dismay of Frognal residents. 

All in all, this year's Community Action is set to be one of the most memorable to date, and it will be fantastic for each and every member of the UCS community to get together and collaborate; not only to create a jovial atmosphere throughout the school, but also to form stronger ties with the local community and to understand some of the incredibly life-changing work that the nominated charities carry out each year.

item.title: Ranulf Road fields graced by rugby legends
item.description:
News
BY MILO NESBITT

A UCS rugby training session was sprinkled with a bit of star quality last month when two England rugby legends coached the Lower Remove team.

Lawrence Dallaglio - a former captain of the English rugby union side - and Jason Leonard, who held the record number of international caps until 2005, arrived at the Ranulf Road playing fields on Thursday, 3rd October.

The pair of greats led the hour-long coaching session - which included a warm-up, drills and general coaching, according to a statement on the UCS website - followed by an opportunity for their 13- and 14-year-old charges to ask them about their favourite career moments and how it felt to play in a World Cup, amongst other things.

Dallaglio and Leonard with the Under-14 team

"Great opportunity"
"It is not often that young boys get to train with such legends. It was a great opportunity for the boys and coaches to develop their rugby skills. Lawrence and Jason bring a unique perspective to our general training and coaching and everyone really enjoyed their visit," said Mr Cooke, Director of Sport at the School.

The event came courtesy of the generosity of Mr Nigel Morris, after he donated the session to the School via an auction for charity: not only was it a fantastic opportunity that the students will never forget, but it was all for a good cause, too.

item.title: Jackson's Action: 'Blue Jasmine' (2013)
item.description:
Culture 
BY MILES JACKSON

Blue Jasmine is Woody Allen’s 45th film since 1966. Take that in for a moment: in 47 years, Allen has directed 45 films. His career has been illustrious, to say the least, punctuated by masterpieces such as Take the Money and Run, Annie Hall, Manhattan and, more recently, 2011’s Midnight in Paris, plus many hits-and-misses in between.

But does Blue Jasmine carry on Midnight in Paris' runaway success? If there's one thing to be said for Blue Jasmine, it’s different from Allen’s usual work. Adopting a far more cynical turn and a serious examination of the impact of the 2008 financial crisis, the film stars Cate Blanchett as Jasmine - or Janette - the wife of a successful businessman.


Jasmine has gone to live with her sister Ginger, a woman who struggles to make ends meet with her two children, whom Jasmine describes having "a taste for losers". The film flicks between past and present as we learn how Jasmine fell from grace and her attempts to recover from her husband’s arrest for tax evasion.

Behind Allen’s trademark sweetness, it’s a really heartbreaking story. Despite Jasmine being a rather unsympathetic character, a freeloader of the 1% of America who only got to her position only by virtue of being married to a corporate CEO, it’s hard not to mourn for her as she descends into madness; this is all owing to Blanchett’s performance.

Blanchett, who is the frontrunner for the Oscar for Best Actress this year, plays a character with vast depth, at first appearing to be a simple caricature of that 1% but revealing herself to be so much more than that. Whilst she’s a little hammy at times, it definitely stands out as one of the best performances of her career.

Indeed, the entire picture is remarkably well-cast, with Louis CK providing a typical Louis CK performance, a detestable Alec Baldwin doing what he does best (being detestable) and, surprisingly enough, a humane and touching Andrew Dice Clay as Augie, collateral damage of the disastrous financial schemes of Jasmine’s husband.

Thematically, it’s a very intelligent and astute piece. In some ways (and I’m not joking here) the themes resemble those of American Psycho. Jasmine is too wrapped up in her own daydream of a life to notice anybody else’s. Most of the film’s conversations are heavily one-sided: Jasmine could be talking to herself and it wouldn't make a noticeable impact on the scene. 

Unfortunately, this metaphor is one that is rammed down the audience’s throat and by the end of the film begins to feel a little tiresome, particularly when the supporting cast, many of whom manage to be more interesting than Jasmine herself, are given so frustratingly little to do. Luckily, this is largely forgivable given that the pay-off at the end of the film puts everything into perspective.

Despite its flaws, Blue Jasmine is a terrifically entertaining film. In typical Woody Allen fashion, the dialogue is whip-crackingly-smart and endearing, whilst the ending will shake you to the core. It’s a twisty, turny and hugely potent film. The non-linear structure is a wonderful fit for Allen’s cautionary tale and whilst it’s a little too explicit in its themes, it’s an interesting and tragic take on the wreckage of the 2008 financial crisis wrapped up in Allen’s trademark style.

Director: Woody Allen
Starring: Cate Blanchett
Compass says: 8.5/10

item.title: Context is everything in a world of rudeness and racism
item.description:
Sport
BY LEO ACKERMAN

A certain word is being scrutinised at the moment in the world of football; a word that many claim is offensive, derogatory and racist. Some Tottenham Hotspur fans, like myself, don't see it at all like that. 

The word is ‘Yid’, and it has come under the spotlight since a campaign by Kick It Out (football’s anti-racism committee who hope to eradicate it within the game) snowballed until many were calling for the banning of the term.


The argument centres around Jewish people: 'Yid' is in fact a shortening of the word 'Yiddish', which is an adjective that refers to Jews in the same way as 'Spanish' describes Spanish people. Now, 'Yiddish' is not an offensive word in the slightest - nobody's doubting that - and it is often used in joke form by many Jews (a classic one being, "If you can't say anything nice, say it in Yiddish!"

The light-hearted camaraderie that surrounds the word 'Yiddish' is a testament to the good nature of the use of this word. However, when the all-important suffix is removed from its end, worlds collide and arguments begin.

The word for Jew in German, 'Jude', was scrawled on shops during the Second World War as a synonym for 'keep out', and it is this association with the Nazi regime that constantly reappears in debates about the word.

The Y-word is sung by Tottenham Hotspur fans as a testament to the club’s Jewish heritage and in no way whatsoever are the songs threatening, offensive or rude. Whilst not all Spurs fans are Jewish, the songs (which include "Jermain Defoe [a Tottenham striker], he's a Yido" and "Yid Army") are sung with passion and a communal spirit. They are not aimed accusatorily at anyone but are simply part of cheering on our team.

"Sense of community"
Of course, there is an argument against the word being used and that is only fair. Like the N-word, many people take great offence to it and rarely is it said out loud. Now here is where the whole issue becomes clouded: the N-word is used fervently in black Hip-Hop music and, again, here the word is usually not used offensively. It is regarded as a collective term to address a group of people - for showing a sense of community - and so the argument isn’t only whether the Y-word or N-words are okay, it’s whether cursing or racial slurs are acceptable in any walk of life. That is simply a matter of opinion, as some are tolerant of cursing whereas some aren't at all.


"Sense of community": Tottenham Hotspur fans at a game.
 (Photo: Cal Sport Media/Rex)

When this does get out of hand, however, is when fans of Tottenham's rival teams, such as Chelsea, West Ham and occasionally Arsenal, start to sing purely racist songs about Spurs' Jewish heritage. A rather delightful Chelsea one goes: "Spurs are on their way to Auschwitz / Sieg Heil! / Hitler's gonna gas 'em again / We can't stop 'em / The yids from Tottenham / The yids from White Hart Lane."

"Poetic horror"
The poetic horror of this chant sends chills down my spine whenever I hear it, and one can find the song on YouTube. This use of the Y-word is clearly offensive and simply disgusting, and with common sense one can clearly see the difference between this and "Jermain Defoe  he's a Yido." Jermain Defoe is a Christian! It is evidently a playful joke! The only one who has the right to have a problem with it is Defoe himself, and in fact he has stated that he actually loves the chant.

I completely understand why some might take offence to the word being used, but some perspective is needed. As a Tottenham fan myself, I have been to the ground and heard these chants. The only malice I have ever sensed in someone’s voice when saying the word was when a balding, rotund middle-aged man shrieked at our goalkeeper, Hugo Lloris, "Oh come on Hugo you c***! Do it for the Yids!".

Context is everything and, please tell me, which is the worst word in that sentence?

item.title: Mums with wads of cash and no knickers try to bribe me for places, says JB Headmaster
item.description:
News
BY COMPASS STAFF

Retiring Junior Branch Headmaster Mr. Douglas has let slip a shocking secret regarding the length parents are willing to go in order to get their sons a place at the prestigious primary school.

The 57-year-old is quoted by the Hampstead & Highgate Express (Ham&High) newspaper as saying he once had a woman approaching him with a "fur coat but no knickers" in an unorthodox attempt to secure her darling offspring entry to Holly Hill.


The much-loved teacher was speaking to parents at Golders Hill School on Finchley Road - a school for 4-to-7-year-old boys and girls, of which a sizeable cohort move on to the J.B. each year after being successful in the 7+ entrance examinations.

Mr. Douglas also revealed that some would-be parents visited his office carrying handbags filled with money and tried to gain their sons' admission to the School by bribery. He is not believed to have taken them up on any of the corrupt offers.

It is thought that the tongue-in-cheek comments were made in reference to the considerable level of demand for entry to the Junior Branch, as Mr. Douglas was one of nine local private school headmasters cultivating prospective parents at the event.

The news comes after a major Ham&High exposé of parents camping outside local independent secondary schools, such as South Hampstead High School, in "Wimbledon-style" queues in a rush to submit application forms for their children.

item.title: Sponsored by 123 Drive! Driving School...
item.description:
Sport
BY JONATHAN TANG

For many years now, a certain UCS pupil has been organizing a football competition in the Community Action term for various year groups. Now, that man is ready to reveal all about how his quasi-revolutionary 5-a-side contest came about.

I alighted upon the idea in Year Six of the Junior Branch, as I saw that it was a fairly straightforward way to raise more money for charity. The year prior to that, I had asked my father to come in to explain what driving a car was like.


He was still working for the illustrious AA Driving School back then, so he visited Holly Hill for a couple of hours, showed the car and it was a success. I thought that with my father's help I could begin to organise events for Community Action.

I created a penalty shoot out competition for two teams from each year and a teachers team which included a selection of staff who could take part 'for a laugh' (though it was oh-so-competitive). It was ultimately won by the Year Four team - who are now in their second year at the Senior School - who comprehensively defeated the teachers, with Mrs. Banihashem scoring the only penalty for the staff squad.

When I moved over to the Senior School, I had the somewhat adventurous idea that my father's infamous driving talk could be exposed to a wider audience - yet the event went downhill after it transpired that Year Twelve students had already been informed about opportunities relating to driving lessons. Several people asked for refunds and I felt it was time to go back to organising football championships.

Established as the '2011 UCS Community Action Lower School 5-a-side Football Competition', with the help of the Community Action team, the tournament was up and running with a terrible start: a pitch invasion, abusive language, multiple cautions and a sending off. It was an opportunity for students to take the proverbial 'mick'!


"Great success" (Photo: Jake Clarke)

After that trauma, which was repeated on the first day of the second tournament a year later, the knockout competition was a success with great prizes. The winning team, 'Darp' (James Benjamin, Ben Case, Dayo Osinuga, Alfie Steiner and Finlay Steel), had beaten 'Majority Jews' (Jack Naftalin, Eidan Zohar, Jack Rifkin, Jonathan Boone, George Spooner and Daniel Simon) and earned the chance to take on the teachers in a special friendly match. I recall that mathematics maestro Mr. Cork was sent off for a two-footed challenge on Ben Case and Dayo Osinuga, although the teachers did emerge victorious after a tense penalty shoot-out.

Now, the competition was firmly in the UCS public eye - along with the slogan of 'Sponsored by 123 Drive! Driving School'. After convincing my father (again) to help me with my Community Action plan, there was further scope for the tournament to expand.

With the addition to a plate competitions, teams could play more and could win a supplementary tournament but this was not to be the case. Another terrible 'first day in the office' - including more pitch invasions and scores of abuse at the referee (me!) - meant that the Community Action team had no choice but to drop the second tournament. I have to admit, I did not want the tournament to stoop to that low, yet it seemed that the Lower School Football Competition was not ready yet.


"Expanded tournament" (Photo: Jake Clarke)

Although I did not hold 'Downtentions' (where if you did not attend my meetings, I would make you watch twenty minutes of Downtown Abbey) the main competition was a resounding success. The winners 'The Jordan Conn Experience' (Jordan Conn, Jonathan Boone, Oliver Clague, Aaron Hamilton, Daniel Simons and Cameron Yousefian) once again earned the right to challenge the staff team, which included the likes or Mr. Enemuwe, Mr. Hind, Mr. Williams and Mr. Allen. The match was accompanied by a live commentary - set up by Mr. Ronald Chung, AV technician - who had helped me throughout the tournament with the technical side to the games.

The game resulted in another penalty shoot-out, with Chelsea fan Mr. Enemuwe taking the last spot-kick. The pressure was on, he stepped up calm and collectively, he placed the ball in the bottom corner and made it a second victory for the teachers' team. Hopefully the winners of this year's Year Ten competition shall finally gain a point for the students.

For the 2013 season, I have made the competition accessible to more year groups. With the integration of the VLE and other such software, participants can access news, photos, results and registration links from the click of a button. We have chosen to adopt a 'World Cup' format for the upcoming tournament, which will initially consist of two groups of four or five teams per year group. Registration is open to year groups from Remove and below, with fees set at £18 per team and all proceeds to charity.

We have decided to continue our longstanding commercial partnership with a certain local motoring company this season. Mr. R Tang, Head of Driving School 123 Drive!, would like to thank all participants for taking part.

* Visit the VLE for more information and follow the links for each year group: https://vle.ucs.org.uk/course/category.php?id=535

item.title: Jackson's Action: 'Gravity' (2013)
item.description:
Culture

With the 57th British Film Institute London Film Festival well underway - having already proven to be a huge success, with films, stars and red carpets to be found all over London - culture reviewer MILES JACKSON reports on an iMax 3D screening of space thriller Gravity.

The film, which is directed by Mexican visionary Alfonso Cuarón, tells the tale of two astronauts stranded in space after a devastating slew of debris destroys their spaceship.


London Film Festival is the first film festival I have ever attended, and what a way to begin what should hopefully be a long and successful relationship with one of the most enduring and esteemed film festivals in the world. Having trekked to the South Bank on one of the most wintry and bleak nights in recent memory, expectations were high for the film, to say the least. With a RottenTomatoes score of 98% (!) and a terrifying trailer to boot, I was hoping Gravity would deliver. And by god it did.

As I sat down in the auditorium, the owner of the BFI iMax entered the room accompanied by a flimsy microphone. He informed us how lucky we all were to be in attendance, how it was the fastest-selling event the cinema had ever hosted and how dozens of famous people had sent in emails asking for tickets, all of whom had been refused. He then unveiled the special guest of the night: it was Alfonso Cuarón.
Sandra Bullock is out of this world

A prodigy in the truest sense of the word, Cuarón is one of the most visually and emotionally progressive directors ever. Though he is probably most famous for his work on Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (an oddball, decidedly different and very Mexican take on the franchise), it's Y Tu Mamá También and Children of Men that are his true masterpieces. He is constantly pushing technology, seamlessly blending it with heart, emotion and wit. Most self-respecting cinephiles will be aware of the shot in 'Children of Men' which lasts over 7 minutes. It’s been 7 years since Children of Men and in that time, Cuarón has been tweaking, perfecting and even just creating the technology required for, dare I say it, his magnum opus: Gravity.

Cuarón, mild-mannered and humble, gave a brief two-minute introduction, ending it by joking that "You can find the air sickness bags under your seat". The kicker was that at many points during Gravity, I really did feel in need of an air sickness bag. Perhaps this was escalated due to my viewing it on a supermassive, iMax 3D screen, but it is truly exhaustive viewing. After the screening I had to walk down to the river in order to catch my breath; in my entire life I had never felt so fortunate to be breathing.

The film's story is deceptively simple: Ryan Stone, played by what is surely an Oscar-worthy performance from Sandra Bullock, is a scientist on her first mission into deep space, installing a device onto the Hubble Telescope. Matt Kowalski, a chipper and witty George Clooney with a jetpack, is the pilot of the space shuttle and is retiring after 20 years. But when a huge wave of debris starts orbiting Earth, Stone and Kowalski are caught in the crossfire, flung out into the depths of space. Now they must do all they can to reach the International Space Station before Stone’s oxygen runs out.

But the film is really about is life and death. Prefacing the picture are some facts about how harsh the conditions of space are, ending with the film’s tagline: "Life in space is impossible". Yet the statement the film truly contemplates is whether life is impossible. It is an existential film in the guise of an action thriller. The film achieves something we last saw in Looper, which is the ability to mesh action with thoughtfulness.

Tweets about "#Gravity"

The action scenes, of which there are quite a few, are some of the best you will ever see. This is where the iMax 3D truly shines. Fittingly, the camera does away with any sense of gravity or physics whatsoever. It spins, lurches and loop-de-loops its way around the Earth, very rarely taking the time to cut. It's nauseous, but in a good way. The kind of nauseous you experience on a rollercoaster. Whilst Stone and Kowalski are the only two characters we see on screen, the camera is the silent third character, bringing the audience closer to the chaos than I'd ever have thought possible.

The camera manages to be even more impressive in the quieter, more contemplative scenes. The solidarity, the depth, the loneliness, the quiet and yet the absolute beauty of the film comes through in every shot. This is in part due to the special effects team, who create the most exquisite depiction of space ever. The score also conveys the delicacy and refinement of the piece. The soundtrack, which contains truly horrifying tracks that inspire massive doses of dread and beautiful, tear-inducing pieces of sheer elegance, matches so well with the grace of the imagery on-screen. One could write an entire book on the complexity and depth of the shots used in Gravity. But, needless to say, they are some of the most technically impressive in the history of film.


"Most exquisite depiction of space"

Cuarón’s script, which he co-wrote with his son, Jonás, is equally as potent as the visuals. The dialogue crackles between the two leads, helped by their fantastic performances. The themes, whilst perhaps too explicit for some, are perfectly balanced with thematic resonance burgeoning throughout the picture. The screenplay is simply a joy to see play out on screen. 

The most interesting part of the script (and again, perhaps this is due to Bullock's masterful performance more than anything else) is the other unseen character of the film. Breath is something we take for granted every day of our lives, and so to see Bullock with such limited oxygen, desperately striving and struggling for a little more air, is painful and tragic to watch. She gulps and rasps throughout the whole film. Not once does it come off as annoying, always managing to harrow rather than harass.

To conclude, as I'm sure you will have guessed having read this review, Gravity is far and away the finest film of the year so far; in fact, it’s the best film of the decade so far. In my opinion, it’s pretty damn flawless. Yes, many of the more logical UCS students will balk at the occasional lapses in scientific realism and the plausibility of some of the situations, but for those of you who can overlook these infinitesimal, insignificant flaws, you'll find one of the best films ever made right here - it really is that good.

Director: Alfonso Cuarón
Starring: Sandra Bullock, George Clooney
Compass says: 10/10

item.title: Video game vilifiers are asking the wrong questions
item.description:
Comment
BY SAM COWLING

As most of you will be aware, roughly three weeks ago was the release of the latest installment in the carjacking, pedestrian murdering and bank robbing smash hit, Grand Theft Auto. However at the same time a survey done by YouGov suggested that 61% of the Britons believe that violence in video games has the ability to cause violence in real life.

I believe that 61 per cent of the British public is wrong. Let me make it astoundingly clear; I am a hardcore gamer. I play more games in a year compared to those most play in five, and I have done so for the last eight years of my life.


So why is this relevant to the question at hand? Well apart from a little bragging rights, I can wholeheartedly assure you that I have seen the media use video games as their scapegoat hundreds of times and it does not become any less infuriating. Contrary to what the media may tell you about gamers, very few of us regularly murder prostitutes and similarly I am pretty certain none of us plan on mowing down a pavement brimming with pedestrians any time soon, so why is it that people who take surveys similar to the one done by YouGov believe we are more likely to become violent?

"Wrong Demographic"
The simple answer – to my mind at least – is that they asked too many of the wrong people. Now I understand that everyone is entitled to an equal view, but YouGov were looking at a very biased demographic. The 60-plus age demographic. Unsurprisingly when asking a selection of people of which many will not have ever played a video game, their views seem a little skewed and out of touch.  In fact 79 per cent of people above the age of 60 believe that violence in games can lead to real world violence, a stark contrast to the 42 per cent of 18-24 year olds who believe the same.

As you can tell I do not take a very profound view of this particular survey, but the issue runs much deeper than a simple questionnaire. After the tragic and despicable events that occurred at the Sandy Hook Elementary school the media were all too keen to admonish people about the dangers of violent video games - one of the apparent causes in their eyes - instead of mourning the unnecessary and horrendous loss of life.

"Easy answers"
Unfortunately there will be cynics among you who think games do in fact cause despicable acts of violence like the Sandy Hook shooting, but I would like to know how many of you remember the names of the children who lost their lives in comparison to how many of you can remember the name of the killer?

Until this problem is addressed, some parts of the media will continue to use video games as the easy answer to everything, after all it is so much easier having things set out in black and white for us. I mean, how absurd would it be to address the true issue of gun laws when we can simply blame video games?

item.title: Top 5: Whistles on screen
item.description:
Culture
BY GABRIEL COX

Film fanatic Gabriel Cox tells The Compass his top five favourite whistles of all time on screen.


5. Kill Bill Vol. 1 (2003)

Daryl Hannah sings the same song as Twisted Nerve below, but this time, she’s on her way to poison the bride, who lies unaware in a coma.




4. M (1931)

Peter Lorre whistles Grieg in this 1931 Fritz Lang film. As you'd expect, it's creepy and sophisticated.



3. Hanna (2011)

Tom Hollander, who plays the German Assassin Isaacs, whistles this nursery-rhyme-esque whistle; the intro to ‘the devil is in the details’ by The Chemical Brothers.


2.  The Wire (2002-2008)

When Omar comes, everybody runs. Omar whistles ‘a hunting we shall go’ while going to rob two drug dealers: the song fits the action.



1. Twisted Nerve (1968)

Hywel Bennett gives this whistle sadism as well as nonchalance, displaying in full the brilliantly psychopathic nature of his character. 


So there you have it- the five best whistles you'll ever see on screen. Have we missed something out? Let us know by commenting below.

item.title: 'Felina': Was it as good as its brilliantly crafted title?
item.description:
Culture
BY LEO ACKERMAN

The finale of Breaking Bad capped one of the most brilliant, ingenious and most of all dark television series of all time. While some will argue The Sopranos, of which I am currently still in season two,  still reigns supreme in the pixelated kingdom, I feel that Breaking Bad was truly the best. While my view may change when I get to the final episode of the magnificent The Sopranos, Breaking Bad spanned 7 months of my life - and I wish it could have been longer.

The plot, for those of you that don’t know (yes, this will contain spoilers), centres around a fledgling chemistry teacher whose life seems to be trundling towards retirement in a dreary suburb of Albuquerque, New Mexico. However, soon after the beginning, Walter White, our 'heroic' professor, discovers he has lung cancer, completely unexpected and unprecedented. Subsequently he runs into an old pupil of his, one Jesse Pinkman, who goes on to become one of the greatest characters ever on TV, and arguably the best in the show. Walt, a rather faint-hearted man at the start of the series, decides he needs to find a way to provide for his family after his unavoidable death.


Therefore, his expansive knowledge of chemistry and incredible brain combines with the raw, street-smart bravado of Jesse: they begin to cook crystal meth together in beaten-up old caravan out in the New Mexico desert. To explain all the daring acts they find themselves doing would genuinely take me 5 or 6 pages to write; that is the brilliance of Breaking Bad.

What makes Walt such a brilliant character is the change in his personality from a completely introverted, withdrawn father to a sinister, threatening and quite truly evil man. While watching ‘Bad’, as it has become known, you do feel like you are watching two characters, Good Walt and Bad Walt. Over the 5 seasons, Walt builds up an empire in south-west America, leading to one of the best quotes in the entire show: “I’m not in the meth business, I’m in the empire business”. And Walt upholds his claims throughout the series that everything he’s done, everyone he’s killed and everybody’s he’s let down has all been for his family. 

That family, which consists of Skylar, his wife; Walt Junior, his late-teen son who has cerebral palsy and the young Holly, who is born in the second season. Walt’s claims of doing all he does for family leads to a certain sympathy towards him, as we feel that none of it is for personal gain. This all changes in the final episode, where Walt explain to Skylar that he wasn’t telling the truth, “I loved doing it… I felt alive”. Walt lying to his wife is a very frequent theme throughout Breaking Bad, and you watch as a relationship is torn apart as Skylar realises she can’t trust anything that Walt tells her.

This final episode, entitled Felina, was quite exceptional. First of all, the title. I mean, who could’ve come up with that but Vince Gilligan, the show’s incredibly gifted creator? FeLiNa, as it probably should be written, is of course an anagram of finale, but also once decoded, one can read it as Fe (Iron), Li (Blood) and Na (Sodium, which is salt, which is in tears). Blood, meth and tears. In truth it doesn't reveal much about the ending, nor would I hope that it should, but it is just a superbly crafted title to such a carefully constructed programme. 

Stars Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul (Photo: UrsulaCoyote/AMC)

More importantly, the actual episode: there were so many moments in ‘Felina’ that amazed me: the use of Badger and Skinny Pete as hitmen with laser pointers, the placing of the ricin in Lydia’s tea and then phoning her to inform her that she was dying, and most ingeniously of all the machine gun turret that obliterated the neo-Nazis on their own turf. It summed up everything about Walt: unexpected, absurd and most of all utterly brilliant. 

If anything, Walt sums up the writers that have constructed this complex show. They too have come up with ideas that no-one ever saw coming; who predicted the hospital explosion where Gus comes out like Harvey Dent in The Dark Knight? Who saw Walt poisoning Brock? If any of you reading truly did predict these events, then I applaud you, as I was left completely shell-shocked when each of those unfolded on my television screen. 

Despite all of this magic, I was left slightly - and I do stress 'slightly' – disenchanted by the ending. Yes, I know that he had to die to provide the series with closure, but I don’t feel it was dramatic enough. It was crucial that we found out he "loved" cooking meth earlier in the episode, as the dreamy look on his face as he perished in his true home (the meth lab) would have been unexplained.

Yet, I didn’t feel gut-wrenched when the final credits rolled. We have probably become so used to that feeling at the end of each Breaking Bad series finale, or even just one episode’s ending, but I was left slightly let down that there was no twist, no revelation, no shock. Some of you may have felt shocked by the way Walt left the world, however for me everything seemed to fit nicely and seal up like a wrapped Christmas present. What I needed was something to change that, something to leave me staring at the screen thinking, ‘Did that really just happen?’. Please don’t get me wrong, by no means was this a bad ending, per se, I just think that it could have been a tad more spectacular.

I have heard a few theories regarding what could or should have happened, and I will share two alternate endings with you now. One, which I very much like, is Jesse shooting Walt when the two were face-to-face in the clubhouse. Had Jesse murdered Walt it would have not been unprovoked, the man had informed Jesse that not only did he poison his closest chance of a son, but that he could have saved the life of Jesse’s only love, Jane. These two bombs might have left someone suicidal, or with a vengeance to carry out, and I think Jesse should have gone through with it. 

The second theory is one that would have given the ending a humorous twist, and some may not have liked it. How fantastic would it have been if Walt had have tried some of his own meth before dying and spent his last few minutes high as a kite off the product he had created? Very Vince Gilligan, and very Breaking Bad… 

Whatever the ending was, it capped off just about the best TV experience I've ever had, and I’m glad that I lived in the time of this show; if you haven’t got the message already: just give it a watch.

Compass says: 10/10

item.title: Why Ben Affleck may mean the death of a hero
item.description:
Comment
BY ETHAN ELSTEIN

I am mourning; I have been mourning for months since I found out the terrible truth… Batman was dead.

I remember the events leading up to the moment vividly. It was a hot afternoon by the pool and I had just dried off and picked up my iPod. After blankly staring at the screen, I tapped on the little Twitter bird. Little did I know what news it would bring as I casually refreshed the page. Whilst scrolling up, a solitary tweet caught my eye. I never knew so much pain could be enclosed in 140 characters. It read solemnly: "Ben Affleck is Batman."


At first, I thought it was a joke, a crude attempt at humour by some lonesome troll. Then, suddenly, more tweets arrived, each proclaiming the same message. It dawned on me that this was no joke; Benjamin Géza Affleck-Boldt was going to play Batman. I began to cry.

For those of you who don’t understand what all the fuss is about, let me set you straight. Batman is the greatest superhero ever. It is a bold but justified claim. The Caped Crusader defeats his enemies, not through some God-given powers, but through strategy and intelligence. His complexities as a character, such as his deep paranoia and inability to trust, make him far more engaging than any other hero. He also kicks butt. Only an intimidating actor can play Batman and combining this with the debonair attitude needed to play Bruce Wayne is a task few actors can manage, certainly not an actor with a history in rom-coms.

It was at this time that I wondered why Warner Bros. and DC had chosen Affleck to star as The Bat instead of other, better candidates. Josh Brolin’s jawline was born to play Batman and he is exactly the sort of dark, brooding character that would fit the bill. Ryan Gosling compliments Batman’s secret identity, Bruce Wayne, as he IS a rich playboy.

And yet, I wonder if Batfleck is such a bad idea. Affleck is an Oscar winner, he has the stature to play a scary hero and having demonstrated his acting ability in recent films: The Town and Argo. Maybe, just maybe, the Dark Knight will rise again.

item.title: Compass Interviews: Philippe Sands, QC (OG)
item.description:
News
BY EMIL SANDS

Last Sunday, I went to interview a former student and now governor of the school. He gave me an insight into the picking and choosing of new Heads, his days at school and how he feels UCS can excel in the future.

Sands begins the interview with "Mr. Durham leaves the school strong, and Mr. Beard’s task is to build on that strength, taking into account UCS values." He goes on to say "Mr. Beard will bring his own views about the academic and cultural direction of the school. It is clearly seen already that, to him, appearance is key along with a strong commitment to academic well being."
On the topic of Mr. Durham's retirement, Sands remarks that "the role of a Head is to inspire, not to impose – Ken Durham did this naturally, and, from what I've seen Mr. Beard will too. It always takes time to adjust to a new hand on the tiller, and I am comfortable that newness soon becomes the norm."

"How does one go about looking for a new headmaster?" Sands introspected for a while and finally remarked: "I think we wanted someone who would take forward all the values of UCS that I so greatly appreciate." This message is a strong one, as Sands has been attached to this school for almost 40 years now, as a pupil, a father, and now a governor. When asked about the picking of Mr. Beard, Sands explains that the board of governors felt "comfortable" with his approach to leadership, and that he would "inspire students and teachers alike to build on the UCS environment." No easy feat. Sands goes on to conclude that Mr Beard "offered a sense of vision, a good vision."


Mr. Sands as a UCS pupil
Compass: "What is your hope for Mr Beard's UCS?"

Sands: "Three main points here: firstly, more of the same but done even better; secondly, think for yourself, that’s certainly what I learnt at my time at UCS; and lastly, the students should want to go to school."

Compass: "The school’s trademark look has certainly changed somewhat, are you surpised by this?"

Sands: "I have picked up different reactions to the new dress code, let’s see how it comes out in the wash!"

Compass: "Leaving UCS as a pupil in 1978, then becoming a father of pupils in the 21st century, to now being a governor, you really have had the UCS 'career' that we are always hearing about. What’s been your favourite position at the school? What’s your UCS secret?"

Sands: "Pupil, undoubtedly. Pupil, then dad, then governor – but they are all brilliant. Let’s just say, we lived through a ‘liberal’ period at the tail end of the swinging sixties."

Compass: "Who started the infamous fire which burnt down the Great Hall?" 

Sands: "We think we know, but if I shared it with you, I would have to silence you. I remember, a few weeks before the great fire, there was an incident in one of my classes, where burning hair was smelt around the school."
Mr. Sands with a School photograph
Compass:  "What are your memories of the old Compass publication?" 

Sands: "Only brilliant! It was a beacon of light and entertainment…and naughtiness. If my memory is still intact, Compass hit the rocks about the time I left with the publication of an issue - in which the front cover bore the words C-O-M-P, and the back cover, A-S-S, above an image of the rear end of the then headmaster’s dog, distinguished by a particularly prominent set of testicles. After that, Compass was no more."

item.title: Whatever happened to Hannah Montana?
item.description:
Comment
BY ED BOYSON-SMITH

As soon as Miley Cyrus burst out of that giant teddy bear, Hannah Montana was dead. Perhaps the scene in which Hannah decided to "shake it like we at a strip club" was on the deleted scenes section of the DVD.

The familiar scene in which Miley Cyrus did the same, however, definitely appeared on the main feature. Miley Cyrus' startling performance at the VMAs, and her newly released, shockingly revealing music video, which perhaps threw her out of the frying pan and into the fire, beg the question: what is the fuss all about?


Yes, it undoubtedly was an eye-catching performance. However, this isn't about Miley Cyrus' infamous twerking routine. This isn't about the flesh coloured, skin-tight, rubber bikini she wore. This is about how a former 'tween' idol has changed her image from good-girl Disney talent to recalcitrant party-girl, and many have stated that the generation that grew up watching Hannah Montana could be encouraged to go down the road of 'slutty, hyper sexualisation' that Cyrus has chosen.

However, this is not necessarily the case – as Cyrus' Hannah Montana persona fades, and Miley Cyrus grows into what should not be classed as maturity, her audience grows up too. It's almost a certainty that many of the young fans of Hannah Montana will be as shocked and disgusted as the rest of the world at Miley's recent charades. Perhaps Miley has inadvertently done her audience a favour, and discouraged teenage girls from following her route - she certainly wasn't very good at 'twerking'.


Others have raised issues about Miley Cyrus' performance in regard to feminism. She would have no doubt enraged feminists by choosing to perform with Robin Thicke, now notorious for releasing a song that can only be described as 'rapey' and 'misogynistic'. True, one may suggest that in making her own choices, she is loosely promoting gender equality, however, she places herself, a woman, as a sexual object in doing so, thus totally contradicting any lazy claims of feminism. It would certainly be more scandalous were a man to display a similarly exorbitant bottom-wiggle in a rubber prison. Whether or not you believe the performance to be derogatory and sexist, I doubt Miley Cyrus had enforcing feminism in mind when she decided to gyrate against Robin Thicke.

Yet, in the end, Miley Cyrus' performance was just a cry for attention. And it worked. The social uproar caused prodigious amounts of publicity for her, and her lewd, raunchy, almost pornographic 'Wrecking Ball' video gained millions of views in a matter of hours. Whilst they may not have been positively received, with many saying that she is barking up the wrong tree with her new 'naughty girl' reputation, one could say that any publicity is good publicity, especially when a new album is due to be released imminently.

It is also unlikely that when Miley Cyrus planned her performance, she had any regard for how it would influence her audience, or how it may appear sexist or derogatory. Why? She knew that such a noticeable performance would provide such an impressive publicity boost. Despite this, Billy Ray Cyrus no doubt has an achy, breaky heart over the evolution, or perhaps devolution, of his daughter. It’s just a shame that the music industry isn't about music any more. Not that it ever was.

item.title: Has the internet blotted out our opinions?
item.description:
Comment
BY ALEX LEVY

I can't say I was pleased to see a recent story regarding comment columns in newspapers. Flicking through a Sunday paper, I realised I couldn't have chosen a worse time to have requested to write articles for The Compass opinion page. The Observer noted their decreasing popularity in these times when opinions are as easily found littered across the internet.

I love the internet. Nothing (well...) has given me greater pleasure than scrawling my shakily-assembled views of the world on sites like Facebook. It has never bothered me that my beliefs are ignored, but I can't help feeling it is my bad luck that is constantly making me write for the less-read type of opinion journalism. Maybe I should stick to my internet philosophy where a misplaced comma isn't frowned upon by a number of readers. It would be easier than inflicting my thoughts on you, so I end up wasting less ink and less time.



Then again, 'opinion' articles are ultimately a written version of a UCS speech in assembly. UCS speeches certainly differ from any mainstream oration - ranging from Mr. Durham's childhood ice cream to the magical properties of particular numbers, to multiple ways of murdering people which makes us wonder whether if Mr. Beard had not become our Headmaster he would have become a writer of crime fiction.

These speeches, however strange, have - at least for as long as I have been at UCS - peaked students' interest; and that makes me ponder the possibility that perhaps opinions of others are noticed by some, despite the lack of internet.

But perhaps there is another purpose of speeches, blogs and these articles. They are not to inform but to provoke thought, because - as self-aggrandising as I am - I don't want to force any belief on you, however much you might disagree. Maybe this column is to illicit opinion rather than to express it.

'Ice-breaker' anecdotes?

I don't think Mr. Durham ever meant for us to gain a good knowledge of the ice cream manufacturing world. Nor do I believe we have been warned to beware the number 23. Neither do I feel that Mr. Beard is intent on us poisoning our relations using cunning Holmesian techniques. The three teachers who have read these speeches have all raised questions after assembly, as was their objective.

And in the same way, I am attempting to provoke thought, and whilst I am not suggesting you slaughter loved ones or ask you to ponder the irrelevance of superstition, I hope to raise questions. The 'opinion' column, as the name suggests, does give a thoughts of the writer, a comment, but also lets the reader develop their own.

But then again, that's just my opinion.

item.title: Music Review: Chvrches, 'The Bones of What You Believe' (2013)
item.description:
Culture
BY THEO ROLLASON

Just when you thought synthpop, a genre commonly criticised for lacking emotion, was well and truly dead, Glasgow-based band Chvrches came along and showed the world that this is a genre with far more to offer.

Since putting the song 'Lies' on the internet to critical acclaim, the band have released three singles, gaining a considerable amount of hype but not much media attention.  Having played at Two Door Cinema Club gigs and toured with Depeche Mode, all seemed to be going well for Chvrches. However, I was unconvinced that the band could match such strong singles with an equally strong debut album.



I can happily say I was wrong to have such doubts; there is not a single bad song on The Bones of What You Believe. From the catchy hooks on 'The Mother We Share' and 'Recover' to the Giorgio Moroder synths on 'Science/Visions', the album is one that gets in your head and is there to stay. 

Above the waves of synths is Lauren Mayberry’s beautiful (yet also rather android-like) voice, which fits into the music so perfectly it almost acts as another instrument. One of the only faults of the album is Martin Doherty’s vocals on the tracks 'Under the Tide' and 'You Caught The Light', which are good but don’t seem to gel with the music as well as Mayberry’s, giving a slight disjointed feel to certain parts of the album.

Lauren Mayberry performing live

Surprisingly for an electronic band, Chvrches’lyrics are also great: “I will be a gun and it’s you I’ll come for” Mayberry sings from the incredibly catchy and somewhat dark 'Gun', while on the slow-building emotional song 'Tether' Mayberry whispers “I feel incapable of saying it’s over”. Through the lyrics there is also a sinister element to the album. While some of the songs are about love, they are most certainly not love songs. On 'Science/Visions' the moaning backings of “hear, hear” and “feel, feel” sound scarily like “burn, burn” and “kill, kill”, and from the title you can just tell that ‘By the Throat’ isn’t the happiest song of 2013. These lyrics and the effects such as the spasmodic breathing on 'Lungs' make the album at times sound like an ‘80s horror movie soundtrack.

While every track on this album is great - any one of the songs could be released as a single - the track that stood out for me was 'Lies': slightly reworked from the song Chvrches originally posted to the internet, its  great chord sequences are complemented by a more bass-heavy sound and vocals with a little bit of attitude to them.

One small problem with the album is that if you’ve been following Chvrches’ musical journey chances are you will know a fair amount of songs on the album. Personally I didn’t feel this was a problem: the singles can be listened to again and again.

The Bones of What You Believe may just be one of the best albums of the year, and Chvrches’ debut has proved that they are no longer just a hyped band; they are a great band. And this won’t be the last we hear from them.

Compass says: 9/10

item.title: Blasphemous, I know, but are holidays too long?
item.description:
Comment
BY SAM COWLING

As UCS students, it is fair to say we are seemingly blessed by interminable holidays that canvas the majority of the year. However, are we losing out by having such a schism in our education every year?

Now, before my classmates berate me for even suggesting that our holidays might be too long, I must admit that nothing is more enjoyable than waking up at two o'clock in the afternoon and eating a takeaway and there may be no sight more thrilling than Phil Taylor claiming his 14th World Matchplay Darts title from the comfort of my own living room.


"Gargantuan holiday"
Yet I can't deny the fact that it is not the most intellectually stimulating lifestyle that I could be adopting in my free time. Although my way of spending the holidays is perhaps more slothful than many of my fellow students, with eight weeks off I have an inherent tendency to believe that I'm meant to be taking time to indulge in the things I enjoy the most.

But, whether or not we benefit from such a gargantuan holiday, I rather imagine that our humble teachers do. I can't think of anyone more deserving: after all, there are so
many times they can keep calm at the sound of the same insipid homework excuses.

Like anything, our holidays have their problems, but the ability for everyone to recharge and prepare for another term is such a huge advantage. At least for the moment, I believe we should overlook the negatives and enjoy our time off so that when we need to work, we’re ready to do so.

item.title: Jackson's Action: 'Rush' (2013)
item.description:
Culture
BY MILES JACKSON

Ron Howard, best known for his thrilling, hyper-realistic work on such docudramas as Apollo 13, Frost/Nixon and A Beautiful Mind, and also for his more family-oriented fare on How the Grinch Stole Christmas (not to mention his slightly less-regarded work on The Da Vinci Code - which we won’t say any more of) reteams with political screenwriter Peter Morgan (The Queen, Frost/Nixon and more recently the successful West End play, The Audience) for this supercharged tale of rivalry between James Hunt and Niki Lauda, two Formula One drivers during the ‘70s.



Peter Morgan has always worked best when he’s writing about two singular individuals and their relationship to each other. And the same applies in Rush. We are introduced to James Hunt and Niki Lauda when they first race each other in the bottom rungs of Formula racing (forgive me if I’m misusing terminology here. I myself have never even watched Formula One prior to this picture!) in Formula Three in the 1970 season.

They quickly establish a rivalry and from here the film plays out like an elongated chess match, leading up to the fateful 1976 season in which their bitter rivalry escalated into a fully-blown feud as they contend for world champion. Every scene, both off the track and on the track, whether they be romantic subplots or brilliantly orchestrated pit stops serves to temper the fiery grudge the two have between each other. And it works brilliantly. This in part lies with the two leading actors. Chris Hemsworth, who plays Hunt, is essentially doing British Thor, but with a little more bravado and raunchiness (it is a 15, after all). Hunt, who wears a badge that reads "SEX - Breakfast of Champions!" (supposedly Hunt really did this), is a brash, handsome “party guy”, as Lauda describes him. Lauda, played by the up-and-coming Daniel Brühl, is the polar opposite. Seemingly alienated to the notion of fun, Lauda drives purely for the money.

Chris Hemsworth as James Hunt
The two characters are very much yin and yang and are played convincingly by the two leads. Whilst they might seem like two-dimensional characters on the surface, the conflicts that play out between the two and their subsequent reactions create characters with depth. Each has their own pros and cons and both are arguably as despicable as each other. Your allegiances will constantly change as the film progresses.

At its core though, this is a movie about racing and unfortunately, the races themselves are a mixed bag. The three major set-pieces in the film, the opening Formula Three race, the fateful events at the Nürburgring racing track and the rain-soaked Japanese Grand Prix are all executed with large doses of tension, grittily and realistically filmed by cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle and are overall a whole lot of fun. In fact, one could even argue that the final race is one of the best set-pieces of the year. 

Despite this, the rest of the races are glossed over, with brief clips showing the scores up on screen. The delegation of screentime means that a lot of the film is one long montage. There are also clear signs of races being cut, presumably due to the relatively small budget the film has in comparison to other entries in the genre.

Furthermore, the romance subplots don’t entirely work, with Lauda’s managing to be compelling and adding to the character whilst Hunt’s falls short, failing to differentiate itself sufficiently from Lauda’s and not adding much to Hunt’s story. It’s disappointing as more screentime could be committed to the races themselves had this strand of the story been cut.

Rush is still a supremely enjoyable film, an intelligent piece filling the gap between the end of the blockbuster season and the beginning of the awards-movie season by fitting both descriptions. Featuring an in-depth character study typical of Peter Morgan’s body of work and a thrilling direction under Ron Howard, it flourishes towards the end of the film despite the large amount of montages in which information is seemingly thrown at the audience’s face. As it stands, it can fit comfortably in both Howard’s and Morgan’s careers, and whilst it won’t be challenging for any Oscars come March, it’s definitely worth your time.

Director: Ron Howard
Starring: Chris Hemsworth, Daniel Brühl
Compass says: 7.5/10

item.title: Theatre Review: 'Hysteria', Hampstead Theatre
item.description:
Culture 
BY JACK STEWART

Hysteria, at first glance, would not appear to be a comedy at all. It is about the terminally ill neurologist Sigmund Freud, who had just escaped Nazi Germany, and his meeting with surrealist painter Salvador Dali.

They are intruded upon by a mysterious girl with a cut-throat razor in the middle of the night, who questions Freud about his psychoanalytic theories.


Sounds like a real barrel of laughs, I know, but Hysteria is actually (forgive me) hysterical. A work of genius, it switches seamlessly between farce and sobriety. It shouldn’t work, but it undoubtedly does. Terry’s Johnson’s writing is sublime and a reason why Hysteria has become a modern classic over the past two decades, emboldened by another entirely outstanding cast.

Antony Sher (Freud), who is known for his more serious theatre roles, proves to be a master of comedy as well. Including his frustrated attempt to get rid of the insanity of Dali (Adrian Schiller), Sher has the audience roaring with unashamed laughter until the curtain falls. Schiller is a brilliant co-star, with a hilarious Spanish accent, dubious grasp of English and a ridiculous pomposity, he generated laughs every time he spoke and sometimes he didn’t even need to do that either.

Lydia Wilson, playing the part of Jessica, the twilight trespasser, also performs superbly as she interrogates Freud on his theories about hysteria. She not only does farce to perfection but manages a full on breakdown on stage - the intake of breath in audience was ostensible while tears streamed down the side of her face.

Hysteria walks the line between insanity, comedy and the serious but does it so extremely well, through the acting, the classic script and thought out direction that the tightrope feels firmly grounded. It is hilarious, uplifting and heartwarming but also disturbing, dark and thought-provoking. In reality, it really is all one could ever ask of a play: you’d be mad not to see it.

Compass says: 10/10

item.title: Exclusive: Battle of the Bands set for a Saturday
item.description:
News 
BY DANIEL WITTENBERG

The 2013 edition of the UCS Battle of Bands music contest will be staged on Saturday 16th November, its organisers have announced.

In a something of a surprise move, the annual event has been scheduled to swap its usual midweek date for a Saturday night, with the aim of attracting a larger audience. Coordinator Isambard Goodbody said: "We think the number of people who are able to come has previously been limited by the fact it was held on a school night and we wanted to avoid that issue on this occasion."


"Excellent opportunity"

It is expected that the charity concert, which generally attracts a 200-strong audience from numerous local secondary schools, will retain a similar atmosphere and level of competition to previous versions.

Isambard, from Upper Remove, said: "It should be a fantastic event as always. We hope to provide an excellent opportunity for people to meet up on a Saturday night and enjoy some high-quality live music. “Battle of the Bands has been the consistently remarkable combination of a prolific fundraising event, as well as a great showcase of rock and alter- native music by an all-encompassing range of UCS students."

Auditions for those vying to take part in the competition were held last Friday (27th September), but bands which are yet to try out are invited to an audition in the Music Department after school today. The final lineup and set list will be announced exclusively on The Compass website in due course, whilst it is unclear whether the teachers’ band will reform in 2013.

"Historic event"
A stalwart of the yearly UCS Community Action programme, Battle of the Bands has been prestigious prize since a group of Old Boys, Bombay Bicycle Club, were propelled to success by the competition.

Isambard added that the organising committee, which also comprises his fellow Year Eleven student Sam Sharrocks, has felt privileged to have been given the chance to stage Battle of the Bands this year. He said: "It is an honour to take up the responsibility of putting on a historic UCS event. We are clearly younger than former coordinators such as Raphael Sonabend and Louis Nye but we aim to do it justice."

Tickets for Battle of the Bands 2013 will be on sale after the October half-term holidays, with all proceeds being donated to Community Action charities in the UK and abroad. The £5 entry fee is unavailable to be charged onto the School bill.

item.title: No blurred lines here, Robin - you got it badly wrong
item.description:
Comment
 BY MILO NESBITT

It was announced recently that Canadian singer Robin Thicke’s “rapey” hit song, Blurred Lines, has been banned from campus bars at no less than five UK universities after it came under criticism for its inflammatory lyrics and explicit video.

Edinburgh, Leeds, Derby, West Scotland and Kingston universities have prohibited the song being included in DJ setlists in their campus bars as part of their stand against "sexual harassment, rape culture and lad banter".


At first glance, this appears to be a case of trigger-happy university officials reading too far into the potentially ambiguous lyrics of a song and wanting to appear particularly egalitarian and avoid any sort of controversy.

But a closer look at the lyrics of the song reveal this not to be the case. Can a song containing the lines "I’ll give you something big enough to tear your ass in two" and "do it like it hurt" ever be passed off as non-derogatory to women? Add that to the apparent defence and trivialisation of sexual assault ("I hate these blurred lines" and "I know you want it") and the track can be viewed as nothing other than creepy and misogynistic.
"Trivialisation of sexual assault": Thicke

Then there’s the video. In case you haven’t seen it, it basically features topless models dancing around a (fully clothed and acting like a sexual predator) Thicke. Again, at first viewing it appears pretty harmless, but there’s clearly something to be said here about the undeniably demeaning portrayal of women, as well as the defamatory representation of the relationship and power dynamic between men and women.

And as if that wasn't enough, an unbelievable but genuine quote from Thicke in the magazine GQ is as follows: "People say, 'Hey, do you think this is degrading to women?' I'm like, 'Of course it is. What a pleasure it is to degrade a woman. I've never gotten to do that before. I've always respected women.'" Whether or not he's joking, saying that was ill-advised at best and downright insulting at worst.

This was, of course, after Thicke tried helplessly to promote his song as a "feminist movement within itself". Now I may be wrong here, but does a video which shows women as nothing more than sex objects for a song containing threatening lyrics go against pretty much every principle of female empowerment or not? Even if he’s not a conscious misogynist, Thicke’s incredibly stupid and arrogant at the very least if he believes that to be true, or even to believe that people will accept that statement.

Obviously merely banning the song will not bring about an end to all sexism. But it does send a message to people like Thicke, and to the rest of the world, that misogyny should not – and will not – be tolerated.

Milo Nesbitt is Deputy Editor of The Compass. You can follow him on twitter here.

item.title: UK school reforms are no match for this lesson in East Asian education
item.description:
Features

Many a-person in the current Upper Remove are aware of an annual pilgrimage I make to Korea - one of the furthest locations from the safe comforts of Frognal on the globe, writes MIN KYOO KIM.

I call the harrowing 12-hour flight a ‘pilgrimage’ because as a migrant who is well aware of all cultures, I have always acknowledged a certain responsibility to aid one understand the other better.


But how do I write an article, for a school newspaper, no less, to shed light and verify Western assumptions on a region of Asia far larger than Mr. Durham’s blessed beard (yes, that big) without sounding arrogant and pretentious? There are two dictators on the Korean Peninsula. Both are notorious: one has ‘nuclear weapons’; the other has some 50 million Koreans under its iron fist, sinister, with no physical embodiment.

Education, as much as Kim Jong-un, dictates the life of a Korean on the peninsula. Whilst I write in my air-conditioned hotel, my 13-year-old cousin returns to school, sweating in the unbearable Korean heat (currently 36 degrees, 89% humidity) after enjoying one of just two month-long holidays. Half terms are an unknown concept here. We at UCS cannot contemplate this, can we?

At 2.30pm he will go straight to compulsory homework club. Two hours later, he will ride his bike to English academy, for another hour - he then comes home, and at 6:30pm, he goes out to maths academy, for ninety minutes of what I can only imagine to be algebra-riddled torture. Finally, at 8pm he saddles his bike, joins his family at dinner before dragging to bring himself with Herculean effort to his desk where towering stacks of homework loom. Is it any wonder Korea has the highest rate of teenage suicides on the planet?

More depressing is the fact said cousin is at relative freedom. I called another uncle upon arriving in South Korea. He was in his car as he picked up the phone - waiting to pick up my 17-year-old cousin from ‘late night academy’ - at half past midnight. Compare this to your own lives in London.

"Stress"
This daunting phenomenon happens every day in Korea for anyone wanting to go to the prestigious Seoul University. Prospects are like dough grinding under a continuous rolling pin of stress, and only those thin enough at the end make the final cut.

So far, my descriptions of student ‘life’ in Korea may have surprised you a little, but it certainly won’t have been wildly differing from your stereotypical expectations. Let me make those assumptions a little more correct. You may think bulldozing parents who cane their kids into educational submission are to blame. In reality, they too are victims of the system.

My aunts and uncles are always bad-mouthing stuttering politicians who talk reform but affect hardly - and whilst I am unable to pinpoint the cause of such a dictated lifestyle, I do not believe parents to be majorly at fault. Parents are the ones caught standing in the middle of a fierce vicious circle.

Would you spare your child from weeks upon weeks of mind-numbing study but certainly guarantee university denial, and a low-pay job in the future? Or do you drag your child into the factory of education, shaping and moulding your child into arithmetic-solving machines, with a high-earning job as a bank manager?

"Ambition"
The latter option is one reluctantly selected by the majority - and that unfortunately means the ‘system’ will be forever perpetuating. Paradoxically, the pursuit for success results in greater chances of failure as competition is only exacerbated as more ambitious parents opt to give their child a steadier pathway to a better life.

We in Britain are incredibly fortunate to be part of an education system that rewards whatever progress is made in any subject. In Korea, maths and science reign. Aspiring musicians become investment bankers; hopeful sportsmen become lawyers. Perhaps it is more sobering on a personal basis that my favourites history and geography, the 'humanities', are considered 'doss' subjects. No wonder stuttering politicians stumble on to the scene.

The understandable motivations of Asian parents consequently results in worsened and all-the-more tough education standards - and that is the true nature of Asian education. It is far, far more violent and vicious than we expect. But what relevance does the hardline Korean education hold for us?

Having witnessed this first-hand with family and friends, I consider myself extremely lucky to be at UCS. I've 'escaped' the prison-like confines of Korean education; but I also acknowledge I must work hard not to waste this incredible chance I’ve been handed. We all are more fortunate than you think. Please make the most of, and importantly, enjoy fully your time here at Frognal.

Min Kyoo Kim is Culture Columnist for The Compass.

item.title: Mr. Bowes-Jones interview transcript - departing UCS royalty reveals all
item.description:
BY DANIEL FRIED
News Editor

At the end of the last school year, Mr Bowes-Jones said goodbye to UCS after twenty-three years of teaching. Throughout those two decades, throngs of UCS geographers have been fortunate enough to witness his unadulterated kindness, his quick-witted sense of humour and his unfeigned fervour for both teaching and Geography.

As the vast majority of the readers of this article will know, there are many rumours surrounding Mr Bowes-Jones’ royal bloodline. These have been a centrifugal discussion point within hushed huddles of Entry boys. During our interview in Mr Bowes-Jones’ final week of school, we aimed to find out if this was idiosyncratic UCS gossip or bona fide fact.


MR. BOWES-JONES: "I am not directly related to the Queen, but there is some truth in the rumours. My mother’s family, the Bowes-Lyon family, is related to the Queen Mother. The Bowes-Lyons are an established Scottish family, with ties to North Yorkshire (from where my mother is from) and Durham."

We then continued to establish if one more contentious whispering was in fact verifiable.

COMPASS: "Is it true that you are leaving UCS to run your Atlanta night-club full time?"

CBJ: "No that's not true, but these rumours have been circulating ever since I started at UCS. A typical example of the mischief of UCS boys, which I’m going to miss so much. I will be spending around six months a year in Atlanta. But there is no night club!"

As all of our more pressing questions had now been answered, it became clear to us just how much Mr Bowes-Jones loved teaching and working at UCS.

COMPASS: "How will you remember your time here? Do you have any anecdotes that particularly stand out?"

CBJ: "I have been at UCS for almost twenty-three years, so I've seen an enormous amount of change. I have so many memories embedded in UCS, as my span here has been so long. I've taught and worked with so many characters over the years, so no, it is hard to pick a favourite. I have many fond memories of my time here. I will miss it very much. I sometimes bump into past students who also have such wonderful memories of UCS. The boys and colleagues have always been characters in their own right - that is the way of the school."

Mr. Bowes-Jones - UCS Royalty bows out


COMPASS: "What is your worst memory of UCS?"

CBJ: "I don't think I have a worst memory. However, what I think will be my worst memory will also be my saddest - the day of my departure in July 2013."

Mr Bowes-Jones' career at UCS saw the arrival of Mr Durham and the new initiatives that he had implemented.

COMPASS: "How would you pay tribute to the retiring Mr Durham?"

CBJ: "As I mentioned earlier, I have been here for all of Mr Durham’s seventeen years, and have witnessed all of his changes. I suppose that introducing girls in Sixth Form is one of the most fundamental and significant. The Headmaster has kept the ethos of the school alive. He’s created a very human place in which to work. He is very concerned about the individual, whether they are a member of the faculty or a student. He genuinely wants them all to succeed and enjoy their time here. I wish him only the best in his retirement."

The retirement of Mr Bowes-Jones and Mr Durham was simultaneous, so he was able to offer up some advice to Mr Beard.

COMPASS: "Do you have any advice for the incoming headmaster?"

CBJ: "Firstly, I want to know why he didn’t appoint me as his academic deputy head. That apart, he should not change the ethos that has fabricated the very special atmosphere of UCS. If he really wants to improve the school, he should move Geography from the Crypt and put it in a more central location. I have been underground ever since I arrived. I’m starting to take on the characteristics of a mole!"

Finally, Mr Bowes-Jones invited "any members of the UCS community" to visit him in Atlanta, where he is currently residing. He also added that "in the past, members of staff have visited. If anybody is ever passing by, feel free to look me up."

With rumours put to rest and Mr Bowes-Jones introspected, he is truly somebody with an enduring connection to the school. If you are reading this, Sir, the UCS community misses your presence greatly and we wish you all the best for the future.

item.title: Jackson's Action: 'Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.' (2013)
item.description:
Culture
BY MILES JACKSON

Riding the coattails of his behemoth The Avengers, Joss Whedon writes (with his brother, Jed, and his sister-in-law, Maurissa Tancharoen, who previously worked together on the lovely Dr Horrible’s Sing-A-Long Blog) and directs the pilot of Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., a new show set in the world of The Avengers. 

With hype already built up through the reveal that Agent Coulson, a character thought dead after The Avengers, would be returning as a main character, Agents has already scored a gigantic viewership of 12.2 million in the US. But was Whedon able to continue his winning streak after Avengers and his recent critical darling Much Ado About Nothing?


As already mentioned, Agents marks the much-touted return of Agent Coulson. Coulson is building up a team of specialists to deal with new superhero-related threats in the aftermath of The Battle of New York. With the help of Maria Hill (Cobie Smulders reprising the role from Avengers), an unstable team of secret agents is built up and immediately sent to investigate a new superhero who goes viral after a clip of his superheroism is uploaded to the internet.

The team itself is comprised of a motley crew of clichés. Agent Ward, seemingly the protagonist, is the typical serious man with a history. Melinda May is the strategist-come-typical serious woman with a history. Agents Fitz and Simmons are the typical comic-relief British scientists who don’t like getting their hands dirty. Of the new characters, only mysterious new recruit and anarchy-enthusiast Skye stands out as an interesting character.

The Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., led by Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg)
The villain, Michael Peterson, feels bullied by life, with no job and a child to take care of after his wife leaves him. But when a mysterious benefactor bestows super powers upon him, he lashes out at “the men in black coats”. Little does he know that the device is loaded with Extremis, the kamikaze substance from Iron Man 3, This is one element of the show that really works, calling back to all the previous Marvel films. One could argue that this makes it difficult for viewers who haven’t seen any of the previous Marvel films, but then again, will there really be anybody watching this show who hasn’t seen the previous Marvel films?

Despite this strong villain, there are a number of flaws within this pilot. The entire show feels like Avengers-lite, with the characters, humour and dialogue not feeling anywhere near as strong as they did in Whedon’s previous Marvel script. The pacing meanders, the show not dedicating much of its runtime to Michael Peterson’s story and instead more to establishing the team. As wise a move as this may seem, it makes the episode’s central conflict feel like an afterthought, lowering the stakes in the process.

However, strangely enough, the episode still manages to work, even with these negative factors in play. This is due primarily to Whedon’s trademark wordplay. Whilst the dialogue is never as strong as Avengers (You won’t find anything as brilliant as Thor’s “He’s adopted” line here), but nonetheless the chemistry between characters crackles. Whilst Whedon relies on tried-and-tested tropes and characters, the end result still manages to entertain, and there’s plenty of potential here for a fun, light-hearted show, even if it at its core a glorified CSI rip-off.

Overall, despite its shortcomings, among them a predictable plot and set of characters, Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. till manages to be a solid piece of Friday night entertainment with a huge amount of potential. Whether that potential will be capitalised upon will remain to be seen. In the meantime, I’ll be sticking with this one, if only to see how it will link to future Marvel movies such as the upcoming Thor: The Dark World.

Director: Joss Whedon
Starring: Clark Gregg, Brett Dalton, Chloe Bennett
Compass says: 6.5/10
